intro: Ranunculus glaber, commonly known as the hairy buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and showy, yellow to orange flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and prefers moist, well-drained soils. Its flowers have five to eight sepals that are often mistaken for petals, and it produces small, hairy fruits that contain several seeds. Ranunculus glaber is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and along stream banks.
